title: Histology dataset template schema
description: Histology dataset template schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.7.1

propertyDescriptions.lab_id: A locally assigned identifier provided by the data provider for the dataset. It is used to reference an external metadata record that may be maintained independently, enabling traceability and supporting provenance tracking. Example: Visium_9OLC_A4_S1.
propertyDescriptions.source_storage_duration_value: The length of time the sample was stored prior to processing it. For assays performed on tissue sections, this refers to how long the tissue section (e.g., slide) was stored before the assay began (e.g., imaging). For assays performed on suspensions, such as sequencing, it refers to how long the suspension was stored before library construction started. Example: 12.
propertyDescriptions.time_since_acquisition_instrument_calibr: The length of time since the acquisition instrument was last serviced or calibrated. This provides a metric for assessing drift in data capture. Example: 10.
propertyDescriptions.contributors_path: The name of the file containing the ORCID IDs for all contributors to this dataset. Example: contributors.csv.
propertyDescriptions.is_image_preprocessing_required: Indicates whether image preprocessing is necessary based on the type of acquisition instrument used, such as a microscope or slide scanner. This may involve steps like fusing image tiles to assemble the complete image. Example: Yes.
propertyDescriptions.is_batch_staining_done: Indicates whether the slides are stained using a linear batch method or individually. Example: No.
propertyDescriptions.is_staining_automated: Indicates whether the slide staining process is automated using an instrument. Example: Yes.
propertyDescriptions.slide_id: The unique identifier assigned to each slide, enabling users to determine which tissue sections were processed together on the same slide. It is recommended that data providers prefix the ID with the center name to prevent overlapping values across different centers. Example: VAN0071-PA-1-1_AF.
propertyDescriptions.tiled_image_columns: The number of columns used in the stitching process of a tiled image, often referred to as the grid size in the x-dimension. Example: 5.
propertyDescriptions.tiled_image_count: The total number of raw tiled images captured, which are intended to be stitched together. Example: 75.
propertyDescriptions.intended_tile_overlap_percentage: The intended percentage of overlap between tiled images. This value serves as the set point, although slight variations may occur during image acquisition due to stage registration. Example: 5.
propertyDescriptions.dataset_type: The specific type of dataset being produced. Default: Histology
propertyDescriptions.analyte_class: The analyte class which is the target molecule that the assay is measuring. Example: DNA.
propertyDescriptions.acquisition_instrument_vendor: The company that manufactures or supplies the acquisition instrument. An acquisition instrument is a device equipped with signal detection hardware and signal processing software. It captures signals produced by assays, such as variations in light intensity or color, or signals corresponding to molecular mass. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". Example: Illumina.
propertyDescriptions.acquisition_instrument_model: The specific model of the acquisition instrument, as manufacturers often offer various versions with differing features or sensitivities. These differences may be relevant to the processing or interpretation of the data. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". If the model is unknown, enter "Unknown". Example: HiSeq 4000.
propertyDescriptions.source_storage_duration_unit: The unit of measurement used to specify the source storage duration value. Example: hour.
propertyDescriptions.time_since_acquisition_instrument_calibr: The unit of measurement used to specify the time since acquisition instrument calibration value. Example: month.
propertyDescriptions.stain_name: The name of the chemical stains or dyes used on histology samples to emphasize key features of the tissue and enhance contrast. Example: H&E.
propertyDescriptions.stain_technique: The staining technique used, which can be categorized into three types: progressive, modified progressive, and regressive. In progressive staining, hematoxylin is applied to the tissue without the use of a differentiator to remove excess dye. In contrast, regressive and modified progressive staining techniques involve the use of a differentiator. Example: Progressive staining.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_instrument_vendor: The company that manufactures the instrument used to prepare the sample (e.g., for staining or other processing steps) prior to the assay. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". If no sample preparation occurred, enter "Not applicable". Example: 10x Genomics.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_instrument_model: The specific model of the instrument used for sample preparation, such as staining. Manufacturers may offer multiple models with varying features or sensitivities, which can influence how the sample is processed and how the resulting data is interpreted. If no sample preparation occurred, enter "Not applicable". Example: Chromium X.
propertyDescriptions.tile_configuration: The configuration of tiles used for stitching in the assay process. If no tile configuration is applicable, enter "Not applicable". Example: Row-by-row.
propertyDescriptions.scan_direction: The direction of imaging, which is necessary for the stitching process. Example: Left-and-down.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_protocol_doi: The DOI for the protocols.io page that details the assay or the procedures used for sample procurement and preparation. For example, in the case of an imaging assay, the protocol may start with tissue section staining and end with the generation of an OME-TIFF file. The documented protocol should also include any image processing steps involved in producing the final OME-TIFF. Example: https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.eq2lyno9qvx9/v1.
propertyDescriptions.is_targeted: Indicates whether a specific molecule or set of molecules is targeted for detection or measurement by the assay. Example: Yes.
propertyDescriptions.parent_sample_id: The unique identifier for the sample (such as a block, section, or suspension) used to perform the assay. For instance, in an RNAseq assay, the parent sample would be the suspension, while in imaging assays, it would be the tissue section. If the assay is derived from multiple parent samples, this field should contain a comma-separated list of identifiers. Identifiers may also include URLs or DOIs that point to the sample resources. Example: 10.1016/j.jchf.2022.08.010.

about.title: about field schema
about.description: about field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.7.1

_ui._content:
About this metadata template

This template provides metadata fields for datasets generated by histology, in alignment with FAIR data principles to promote data sharing and reuse. Structured metadata enhances the discoverability, accessibility, interoperability, and reproducibility of biomedical research data.

Developed through community efforts within the HuBMAP and SenNet consortia, the template leverages the CEDAR Workbench platform for streamlined metadata authoring and management. These efforts contribute to enabling broad, consistent data sharing across the research community in accordance with NIH data sharing policies.

For assistance, please visit the HuBMAP Contact page or the SenNet Contact page.

Funding: This work was supported in part by IEC-HuBMAP (NIH Award OT2OD033759), IEC-SenNet (NIH Award xx), Penn-DCWG (NIH Grant U54HD104392), and Stanford-CEDAR (NIH Grant U54AI117925).

Citation: Use the following reference to cite the metadata specification: xx

about.schema:name: about

_valueConstraints.defaultValue: This schema provides a community standard for describing datasets generated by histology to promote FAIR data sharing across research communities. Developed by HuBMAP and SenNet using the CEDAR Workbench. Funding: IEC-HuBMAP (NIH Award OT2OD033759), IEC-SenNet (NIH Award xx), Penn-DCWG (NIH Grant U54HD104392), Stanford-CEDAR (NIH Grant U54AI117925).

acknowledgement.schema:name: acknowledgement

schema:name: Histology Dataset
schema:description: The histology metadata specification provides standardized guidelines for organizing and describing histological data, facilitating efficient analysis and interpretation.
